frameDefinitions: This frame concerns the appointment of a New_leader or removal from office of an Old_leader.
In this frame, a Communicator judges the Addressee and then communicates that appraisal directly to the Addressee.
In this frame, an Authority allows a Protagonist to know (in some way) that they may or may not engage in an Action.
A Ratifier responds to a Proposal constructed by another party to make it binding over the Ratifier's jurisdiction or constituency.
Partner_1 interacts with Partner_2 (also collectively expressible as Partners) to change their social relationship.
A Signatory signs an Agreement document, thereby taking on a commitment encoded in the Agreement.  '.
frameExamples: On March 17 , Mamedov <t>appointed</t> Rakhim Gasiyev as Defence Minister .
The principal <t>rebuked</t> the student for cheating on the exam.
The police officer <t>forbid</t> me from turning around .
The <t>ratification</t> of the Kyoto protocol has been a long, hard slog.
I <t>befriended</t> the little pony by giving him a piece of apple.
. During this time, 84 countries (including the United States) <t>signed</t> the Protocol.
listRoleDefinitions: The Selector (most commonly a group of people) is responsible for a change in leadership.  Typically, it occurs as the External Argument of verbs.

With words denoting removal (or attempted removal) from office of a leader, the <fen>Old_leader</fen> is typically the direct object of verbs, or occurs in a PP Complement with noun targets, frequently headed by the preposition <ment>against</ment>.
With words denoting appointment to a position, the <fen>New_leader</fen> is typically the object of verbs.

Frequently the <fen>Old_leader</fen> or <fen>New_leader</fen> is referred to only by his/her role. However, the <fen>Role</fen> can be expressed separately from the leader, usually as either a secondary predicate or in a PP Complement.
The role <fen>Old_order</fen> identifies the political order that existed before the change of leadership occurs.
The <fen>Function</fen> is the purpose the <fen>New_leader</fen> will fufill.
A group of individuals who are elected or appointed to perform some function of governance.
When the change takes place.
Where the change takes place.
The <fen>Communicator</fen> communicates a judgment to the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
The <fen>Addressee</fen> is jduged by the <fen>Communicator</fen> and receives the message of approval or disapproval.
The <fen>Topic</fen> is the subject on which the <fen>Addressee</fen> is being judged.
The <fen>Reason</fen> is why the Communicator forms the type of judgment they form.
The <fen>Medium</fen> identifies the physical or abstract entity in which the judgment is conveyed.
An action or entity under the control of the <fen>Communicator</fen> that expresses the criticism or praise directed towards the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
The point in time at which the <fen>Communicator</fen> berates or compliments the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
The location where the <fen>Communicator</fen> admonishes the <fen>Addressee</fen>.
The <fen>Authority</fen> orders the <fen>Protagonist</fen> to not engage in a particular <fen>Action</fen>.
The <fen>Protagonist</fen> wants to engage in an <fen>Action</fen>, but is ordered not to by the <fen>Authority</fen>.
The <fen>Action</fen> is what the <fen>Protagonist</fen> seeks to do, but is ordered not to.
The <fen>Time</fen> is when the denying of permission occurs.
The <fen>Place</fen> is where the denial of permission occurs.

The individual or body that confirms a Proposal negotiated or created by another party, causing it to become binding in a jurisdiction represented by the <fen>Ratifier</fen>.  In the case of direct democratic ratification, the jurisdiction and the <fen>Ratifier</fen> are the same.
The idea or course of action proposed by another individual or body which the <fen>Ratifier</fen> endorses and makes binding.
The <fen>Time</fen> is when the <fen>Ratifier</fen> makes the <fen>Proposal</fen> binding.
The <fen>Place</fen> is where the <fen>Ratifier</fen> ratifies the <fen>Proposal</fen>.
The individual who comes to form a relationship with Partner_2.
The individual whose relationship with <fen>Partner_1</fen> changes.
The individuals whose relationship is changing.
The time when the relationship changes.
Where the relationship is formed.
The signatory of the <fen>Agreement</fen>.
The entity signifying the identity of the <fen>Signatory</fen>, resulting from the act of writing on the <fen>Agreement</fen> document.
The document which encodes the commitment of the <fen>Signatory</fen>.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> at which signature is given.
The place where the signing occurs.
listRoleExamples: <fex>The voters</fex> elected Blair.
The students overthrew <fex>the president</fex>.
The president appoints <fex>the prime minister</fex>.
The board of directors appointed Ashton <fex>Acting President</fex>.
The rebels overthrew <fex>the dictatorship</fex>.
His district elected her  <fex>to Congress</fex> three times.
The <fex>2000</fex> coup against the dictator was led by former president Smith.
The crew mutinied <fex>out in the middle of the Atlantic</fex>, the scoundrels.
The teacher scolded the children <fex>about their meessy cookie eating</fex>.
The principal rebuked the student <fex>for cheating on the exam</fex>.
Though she had killed him so long ago, she could still see his jeering <fex>smile</fex>.
She complimented me <fex>almost every morning</fex> on my smart starched shirts.
We were scolded <fex>in the kitchen</fex> by the biggest cook you've ever seen.
If <fex>we</fex> ratify Management 's plan , we 'll have to take a drug test every week !
President Aleksander Kwasniewski ratified <fex>protocols to the Europol Convention</fex>.
She married Stephen <fex>last summer</fex>.
We married <fex>in a gazebo</fex>.
<fex>Eisenhower</fex> signed a treaty  with aliens.
The Attorney General seemingly never put his <fex>signature</fex> on the agreement.
I signed <fex>the contract</fex> and now the dealership claims they made a mistake, quoted the price too low and now I have to pay them more money.
